{{Unreferenced|date=January 2008}}
The '''Hardware Information Navigational Tool''', or '''HINT''', is an information web service developed by the former AG Communications Systems (now [[Alcatel-Lucent]]) which displays hardware and software characteristics of a [[telephone exchange|central office]] switching system. It displays the hardware equipment as it is positioned in the central office and shows how this equipment is being used. The program displays an interactive map, allowing the user to select the applicable states/provinces or country, then select the switching system, and then finally the module, circuit pack, and circuit. The statistical reports allow customers to maintain a watch on their resources. It is also useful for engineering and the daunting task of assigning all of the various telephony services.
All [[telephone exchange]]s are customized to local conditions. Because of this, there exists a dynamic difference between one central office to another due to capacity, provided features, and hardware vintages. HINT started out as an internal resource used by [[GTD-5 EAX]] Engineering Services, Remote Technical Assistance, and Sales Support. It was created with the intent to accurately view a customer’s unique hardware configuration without physically being present at the site. Deciphering the switch’s own Office Dependent Data (ODD), it provided switching system hardware images that were accurate and up-to-date. Through internal feedback and subsequent modifications, it evolved into a tool that was viable enough to be offered as a product and sought after by customers.
Due to the similarities between the GTD-5 EAX and the [[5ESS]] product lines, numerous requests were made by HINT users to develop and expand the scope of HINT so that it includes the 5ESS switching system. After hearing the same request for several years and realizing the revenue potential of adding the 5ESS, AG expanded HINT to include the 5ESS switch type, providing the same features, look, and feel that has made the GTD-5 EAX version so popular.
Presently {{When|date=February 2011}}, over 90% of GTD-5 EAX switching systems are supported and maintained by the customer using HINT. These [[telephone company|users]] have been using the tool for several years and purchase the service as a yearly subscription subject to annual scrutiny and review. Because of this, the vendor is continuously upgrading and adding new features to excite interest and retain its customer base.
==See also== *[[Operations support systems]]
[[Category:Telecommunications systems]]

The '''International Press Telecommunications Council''' ('''IPTC'''), based in [[London]], [[United Kingdom]], is a [[consortium]] of the world's major [[news agencies]], other news providers and news industry vendors and acts as the global [[List of technical standard organisations|standards body]] of the news media.
Currently more than 50 companies and organizations from the news industry are members of the IPTC, including global players like [[Associated Press]] (AP), [[Agence France-Presse]] (AFP), [[Deutsche Presse-Agentur]] (dpa), [[BBC]], [[Getty Images]], [[Press Association]] (PA), [[Reuters]] and ''[[The New York Times]]''.
IPTC aims at simplifying the distribution of information. To achieve this technical standards are developed to improve the management and exchange of information between content providers, intermediaries and consumers. IPTC is committed to open standards and makes all standards freely available to its members and the wider community.
The IPTC was established in 1965 by a group of news organisations including the [[European Alliance of News Agencies|Alliance Européenne des Agences de Presse]] (EANA), American Newspaper Publishers Association (then ANPA, now [[Newspaper Association of America|NAA]]), Fédération Internationale des Editeurs de Journaux (now [[World Association of Newspapers and News Publishers|WAN-IFRA]]) and the North American News Agencies (a joint committee of [[Associated Press]], [[Canadian Press]] and [[United Press International]]) to safeguard the telecommunications interests of the world's press.
== IPTC Standards ==
=== Photo metadata ===
The IPTC defined a set of [[metadata]] properties that can be applied to images, part of a broader standard developed in the early 1990s and known as the [[IPTC Information Interchange Model]] (IIM). Embedded IIM image information is often referred to as an "IPTC header". This basic set of metadata fields is branded as ''IPTC Core'', in 2008 a second set branded as ''IPTC Extension'' was developed.
The [[Extensible Metadata Platform]] (XMP) has largely superseded IIM's image file header structure, but the properties of the IPTC Core are synchronized between the technical structures of XMP and IIM by a vast majority of imaging software.
Because of its nearly universal acceptance among photographers — even amateurs — this is by far IPTC's most widely used standard.
=== IPTC NewsML-G2-Standards Family === Using XML and the W3C’s model for the [[Semantic Web]], in 2008 IPTC launched a new series of standards that feature modular construction and many opportunities for embedding metadata. This allows developers to build applications that use only the parts of the IPTC NewsML-G2-Standards that are required by the customer, and that reduce programming costs by re-using XML and metadata modules. Further the NewsML-G2-Standards extend the scope of exchange formats beyond news content, they include event data and well organised information about persons, organisations, points of interest, geopolitical areas or abstract concepts.
These members of the family of standards are available now: [[NewsML-G2]], [[EventsML-G2]] and [[SportsML-G2]]. Although they have different roles within the news industry they share much of the date model and the same XML coding.
====NewsML-G2==== [[NewsML-G2]] acts as an envelope and organizer so that news providers can create single news items — text, photos, video or anything else — and bundle them into concise cohesive packages than can be automatically processed by web CMSs or newsroom systems. The content and relationships of the individual news items can be described using a rich set of [[metadata]].
NewsML-G2 is not a text or image mark-up format. For example, it does not contain paragraph or headline tagging. Rather, it is an envelope and organizer that does not, by itself, act as a content format.
====EventsML-G2==== [[EventsML-G2]] optimises the sharing of event information such as meetings, sports events, elections, and even rocket launches — virtually any announced activity that can be broadly classified as an "event." Using XML and metadata, EventsML-G2 allows news providers to create rich descriptions of events plus information about planned coverage, and then share that information with web sites, databases, newsrooms or other customers.
====SportsML-G2==== [[SportsML-G2]] is a convenient way to share sports statistics in a concise, unambiguous way. All major sports are supported, and certain sports that are known for rich or especially complex statistics (such as [[baseball]]) can use special add-on modules. SportsML-G2 has found wide usage outside the news industry; among the user communities are sports teams, [[fantasy sports]] leagues, sports betting firms and sports historians. SportsML-G2 is the newer sibling of [[SportsML]].
===NewsCodes=== NewsCodes is the branding of [[Controlled vocabulary|Controlled Vocabularies]] created and maintained by IPTC. A set of them can be used to classify news content - regardless of the media type - and another set is used to support the functionality of IPTC's news exchange format standards.
===NewsML 1=== [[NewsML]] 1 is an XML standard developed by the IPTC to provide a media-independent, structural enveloping framework for multi-media news. It was recently superseded by [[NewsML-G2]], although IPTC plans to support this standard as ''NewsML 1.x'' indefinitely.
===ninjs=== ninjs standardizes the representation of news in [[JSON]] - a lightweight, easy-to-parse, data interchange format. The format covers the data interchange by APIs and documents in content management systems like search engines.
==={{anchor|NITF}}NITF - News Industry Text Format=== [[News Industry Text Format]] (NITF) is an XML specification published by the IPTC that is designed to standardize the content and structure of text-based news articles.
===RightsML=== RightsML is IPTC's [[Rights Expression Language]] for news media and is based on [[ODRL]].
===rNews=== rNews is a standard for using semantic markup to annotate online news. It defines a data model for embedding machine-readable publishing metadata in web documents and a set of suggested implementations. Some properties of this standard have been adopted by [[Schema.org]] for its metadata schema.
===SportsML=== [[SportsML]] is a convenient way to share sports statistics in a concise, unambiguous way. All major sports are supported, and certain sports that are known for rich or especially complex statistics (such as [[baseball]]) can use special add-on modules. SportsML has found wide usage outside the news industry; among the user communities are sports teams, [[fantasy sports]] leagues, sports betting firms and sports historians. The newer sibling of SportsML is [[SportsML-G2]].
===IPTC 7901=== [[IPTC 7901]] is still a widely used format for plain text news, despite being 30 years old. It is a close relative of the [[Newspaper Association of America]] North American standard [[ANPA-1312]], and uses similar control and other special characters to create a file that can be used to drive computerized news editing systems, photo typesetters or even [[teleprinter]] machines.
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * {{Official website|https://iptc.org/}} ** [https://iptc.org/participate/membership/current-members/ Current members] ** [https://iptc.org/standards/photo-metadata/ Photo Metadata] ** [https://iptc.org/standards/iptc-7901/ IPTC 7901] ** [https://iptc.org/standards/media-topics/ Media Topics] * [https://iptc.org/standards/newsml-1/ NewsML] * [https://iptc.org/standards/newsml-g2/ NewsML-G2] * [https://iptc.org/standards/eventsml-g2/ EventsML-G2] * [https://iptc.org/standards/newscodes/ NewsCodes] * [https://iptc.org/standards/ninjs/ News in json] (ninjs) * [https://iptc.org/standards/rightsml/ RightsML] * [https://iptc.org/standards/rnews/ rNews] * [https://iptc.org/standards/sportsml-g2/ SportsML-G2] * [https://iptc.org/standards/nitf/ NITF]
[[Category:International organisations based in London]] [[Category:Metadata]] [[Category:News agencies based in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:1965 establishments in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Organisations based in the City of London]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1965]] [[Category:Standards organisations in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Technology trade associations]]

{{Infobox journal | title = Journal of Power Sources | cover = | editor = Stefano Passerini | discipline = [[Electrochemistry]] | former_names = | abbreviation = J. Power Sources | publisher = [[Elsevier]] | country = | frequency = Biweekly | history = 1976-present | openaccess = | license = | impact = 6.945 | impact-year = 2017 | website = http://www.elsevier.com/wps/find/journaldescription.cws_home/504093/description | link1 = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/journal/03787753 | link1-name = Online access | link2 = | link2-name = | JSTOR = | OCLC = | LCCN = | CODEN = | ISSN = 0378-7753 | eISSN = }} The '''''Journal of Power Sources''''' is a [[Peer review|peer-reviewed]] [[scientific journal]] covering all aspects of [[electrochemical energy conversion]] (like [[fuel cell]]s, [[Battery (electricity)|batteries]], [[supercapacitor]]s, and [[Photoelectrochemical cell|photo-electrochemical cells]]). The current [[editors-in-chief]] is Stefano Passerini,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.elsevier.com/wps/find/journaleditorialboard.cws_home/504093/editorialboard |title=Journal of Power Sources: Editorial Board |publisher=Elsevier}}</ref> According to the ''[[Journal Citation Reports]]'', the journal has a 2017 [[impact factor]] of 6.945 and a 5-year impact factor of 6.496.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://jcr.incites.thomsonreuters.com/JCRJournalProfileAction.action?pg=JRNLPROF&journalImpactFactor=6.945&year=2017&journalTitle=JOURNAL%20OF%20POWER%20SOURCES&edition=SCIE&journal=J%20POWER%20SOURCES|title=InCites|last=|first=|date=|website=jcr.incites.thomsonreuters.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-10-12}}</ref>
Until December 2009, the journal was published in many "small" volumes which contained typically 2 issues. In the years 2010 and 2011, the journal tried to adopt the "one volume per year" convention common outside Elsevier. Starting January 2012, however, it decided to completely abandon the issue numbers and became a volume-only journal.
== References == <references />
== External links == * {{Official website|http://www.elsevier.com/wps/find/journaldescription.cws_home/504093/description}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Journal Of Power Sources}} [[Category:Electrochemistry journals]] [[Category:Energy and fuel journals]] [[Category:Elsevier academic journals]] [[Category:Biweekly journals]] [[Category:Publications established in 1976]] [[Category:English-language journals]]

revision.text:
[[File:Cylindre de Leibniz animé.gif|right|thumb|In the position shown, the counting wheel meshes with three of the nine teeth of the Leibniz wheel.]] [[File:Mechanical-calculator-Brunsviga-15-01.jpg|thumbnail|Mechanical calculator Brunsviga 15 with removed shrouds.]] A '''Leibniz wheel''' or '''stepped drum''' is a cylinder with a set of teeth of incremental lengths which, when coupled to a counting wheel, can be used in the calculating engine of a class of [[mechanical calculator]]s. Invented by [[Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz|Leibniz]] in 1673, it was used for three centuries until the advent of the [[electronic calculator]] in the mid-1970s.
[[Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz|Leibniz]] built a machine called the [[stepped reckoner]] based on the design of the stepped drum in 1694.<ref>[[#IFRAH|Ifrah, p. 125 (2001)]]</ref> It was made famous by [[Thomas de Colmar]] when he used it, a century and a half later, in his [[Arithmometer]], the first mass-produced calculating machine.<ref>[[#CHASE|Chase, p.204 (1980)]]</ref> It was also used in the [[Curta calculator]], a very popular portable calculator introduced in the second part of the 20th century.
==Concept== By coupling a Leibniz wheel with a counting wheel free to move up and down its length, the counting wheel can mesh with any number of teeth.
The animation on the side shows a nine-tooth Leibniz wheel coupled to a red counting wheel. It is set to mesh with three teeth at each rotation and therefore would add or subtract 3 from the counter at each rotation.
The computing engine of an Arithmometer has a set of linked Leibniz wheels coupled to a crank handle. Each turn of the crank handle rotates all the Leibniz wheels by one full turn. The input sliders move counting wheels up and down the Leibniz wheels which are themselves linked by a carry mechanism.
From the late nineteenth century on, Leibniz stepped drums in purely mechanical calculators were partially supplanted by [[Pinwheel calculator|pinwheels]] which are similar in function but with a more compact design; stepped drums remained the primary technology for electromechanical calculators until the development of purely electronic calculators.
==Machines built using this principle== [[File:Leibnitzrechenmaschine.jpg|thumb|Replica of Leibniz's Stepped Reckoner in the [[Deutsches Museum]].]] * {{flagicon|Germany}} – [[Gottfried Leibniz]] built his first stepped reckoner in 1694 and another one in 1706.<ref>[[#MARGIN|Marguin, p.65 (1994)]]</ref> * {{flagicon|Germany}} – Philipp-Matthäus Hahn, a German pastor, built two circular machines in 1770.<ref>[[#MARGIN|Marguin, p.83 (1994)]]</ref><ref>[http://www-03.ibm.com/ibm/history/exhibits/attic/attic_137.html Picture of Hahn's Calculator] IBM Collection of mechanical calculators</ref> * {{flagicon|Germany}} – J.C. Schuster, Hahn's brother in law, built a few machines of Hahn's design into the early 19th century.<ref>[[#MARGIN|Marguin, p.84-86 (1994)]]</ref> * {{flagicon|United Kingdom}} – [[Charles Stanhope, 3rd Earl Stanhope|Lord Stanhope]] designed a machine using Leibniz wheels in 1777. He also designed a [[pinwheel calculator]] in 1775.<ref>[[#FELT|Door E. Felt, p.15-16 (1916)]]</ref> * {{flagicon|Germany}} – Johann-Helfrich Müller built a machine very similar to Hahn's machine in 1783. * {{flagicon|France}} – [[Charles Xavier Thomas|Thomas de Colmar]] invented his [[Arithmometer]] in 1820 but it took him 30 years of development before it was commercialized in 1851. It was manufactured until 1915. Louis Payen, {{nowrap|Veuve L. Payen}} and Darras were successive owners and distributors of the Arithmometer. * {{flagicon|France}} – Timoleon Maurel invented his [[Arithmaurel]] in 1842. The complexity of its design limited its capacity and doomed its production, but it could multiply two numbers by the simple fact of setting them on its dials. * {{flagicon|Europe}} – About twenty clones of the Arithmometer were manufactured in Europe starting with Burkhardt in 1878 then came Layton, Saxonia, Gräber, Peerless, Mercedes-Euklid, XxX, Archimedes, TIM, Bunzel, Austria, Tate, Madas etc. These clones, often more sophisticated than the original arithmometer, were built until the beginning of World War II. * {{flagicon|United Kingdom}} – Joseph Edmondson invented and manufactured a circular calculator in 1885.<ref>[http://www.rechenmaschinen-illustrated.com/Edmondson.htm Pictures of the Edmonson calculator] www.rechenmaschinen-illustrated.com</ref> * {{flagicon|United States}} – Friden and Monroe calculators used a biquinary variant of this mechanism. Both were made in large numbers; Monroe started early in the 20th century; Friden in the 1930s. (The Marchant used a radically different and unique mechanism.) The variant mechanism worked with digits from 1 through 4 as shown in the animation; digits larger than 4 engaged a five-tooth gear as well as the teeth of the Leibniz wheel. This made it unnecessary for the sliding gear to travel longer distances for the higher-number digits. Otherwise, pressing a 5..9 key would require either a longer stroke (as in a Comptometer) or excessive force combined with a gently sloping cam surface. * {{flagicon|Austria}} – [[Curt Herzstark]] introduced his [[Curta Calculator|Curta]] portable calculator in 1948, which remained popular until the introduction of electronic calculators in the 1970s.
==Notes== {{Reflist}}
==Sources== {{refbegin}} *{{cite book|title=History of Mechanical Computing Machinery. Volume 2, Number 3|last=Chase|first=George C|date=July 1980|publisher=IEEE Annals of the History of Computing|ref=CHASE}} *{{cite book|title=The Universal History of Computing|first=Georges|last=Ifrah|year=2001|publisher=John Wiley & Sons, Inc|isbn=0-471-39671-0|ref=IFRAH}} *{{cite book|language=fr|title=Calculus|first=Luc|last=de Brabandere|year=1995|pages=114–125|publisher=Mardaga|location=Paris|isbn=978-2-87009-591-1|ref=CALCULUS}} *{{cite book|language=fr|title=Histoire des instruments et machines à calculer, trois siècles de mécanique pensante 1642-1942|first=Jean|last=Marguin|year=1994|publisher=Hermann|location=|isbn=978-2-7056-6166-3|ref=MARGIN}} {{refend}}
== External links == * [http://www.arithmometre.org/indexEnglish.html Arithmometre.org - Main page] - The first commercially successful machine that used Leibniz wheels * [https://web.archive.org/web/20170202040444/http://www.ami19.org/indexEnglish.html ami19.org] - A great site for patents and articles on 19th century mechanical calculators * [http://www.rechenmaschinen-illustrated.com/pictures_Thomas.htm Rechenmaschinen-Illustrated] - A large display of mechanical calculators
{{DEFAULTSORT:Leibniz Wheel}} [[Category:Gottfried Leibniz]] [[Category:Mechanical calculators]]

[[File:Lombard Log Hauler 38.jpg|thumb| Lombard Log Hauler #38, built ca. 1910, restored in 2014 by the University of Maine Mechanical Engineering Technology class of 2014 and the Maine Forest and Logging Museum.]] [[File:Lombard steam log hauler.jpg|thumb|300px|right|A restored Lombard steam log hauler at [[Clark's Trading Post]] in [[Lincoln, New Hampshire]]]] The '''Lombard Steam Log Hauler''', patented 21 May 1901, was the first successful commercial application of a continuous track for vehicle propulsion.<ref>Alvin O. Lombard, Logging Engine, {{US patent|674737}}, granted May 21, 1901.</ref><ref>Alvin O. Lombard, Log Hauler, {{US patent|854364}}, granted May 21, 1907.</ref><ref name="auman">Auman (1984) p.99</ref> The concept was later used for military [[tank]]s during [[World War I]] and for agricultural tractors and construction equipment following the war.
==Description== [[Alvin Orlando Lombard]] was a blacksmith building [[logging]] equipment in [[Waterville, Maine]]. He built 83 steam log haulers between 1901 and 1917.<ref name="Auman_a">Auman (1984) p.100</ref> These log haulers resembled a [[Tank locomotive#Saddle tank|saddle-tank]] [[steam locomotive]] with a small platform in front of the boiler where the [[pilot (locomotive)|cow-catcher]] might be expected. A steering wheel on the platform moved a large pair of [[ski]]s beneath the platform. A set of [[Continuous track|tracked vehicle]] treads occupied the space beneath the boiler where [[driving wheel]]s might be expected. The locomotive [[cylinder (locomotive)|cylinders]] powered the treads through a [[gear]] train. The log haulers mechanically resembled 10- to 30-ton [[snowmobile]]s with a top speed of about {{convert|4.5|mph}}.<ref>Holbrook (1961) pp.77-80</ref>
==Operation== While the ground was covered with snow and ice, a log hauler could tow a string of [[sled]]s filled with logs. Each sled train required a crew of four men. An [[railroad engineer|engineer]] and [[fireman (steam engine)|fireman]] occupied the cab behind the boiler, and a steersman sat on the platform in front. A [[conductor (rail)|conductor]] rode on the sleds with a bell-rope or wire to signal the crew in the cab.<ref>Holbrook (1961) p.78</ref> The earliest log haulers pulled three sleds, and later models were designed to pull eight sleds. Each train carried 40,000 to 100,000 [[board foot|board-feet]] of logs. The record train length was said to be 24 sleds with a total length of {{convert|1650|ft}}.<ref name="Auman_a" />
The greatest operational difficulty was on downhill grades where ice allowed the sleds to accelerate faster than the engine. Jack-knifing sleds pushed many log haulers into trees, and most photos of log haulers show rebuilt cabs and bent ironwork on the boiler and saddle tank. [[Hay]] was spread over the downhill routes in an effort to increase friction under the sleds, but hungry deer sometimes consumed the hay before the train arrived.
The steersman was regarded as the hero of the crew. In sub-freezing temperatures down to 40 degrees below zero, he sat in an exposed position in front of the train. Sparks flying out of the boiler stack above him would sometimes set his clothing afire as avoidance of trees required his full attention and effort turning the clumsy steering wheel. Some steersmen earned enough money to purchase fire-resistant leather clothing. Some log haulers had a small roofed shelter built on the steering platform, but the shelter limited the steersman's ability to jump clear when collision became inevitable, and few were able to avoid injury from the following trainload of logs.
[[Brown Company#Berlin Mills Company |Berlin Mills Company]] was one of the larger woods operators to use Lombard log haulers. They purchased one machine in 1904, and then purchased two more to maintain reliable operation when one needed repairs. The company maintained a single {{convert|6|mi|km|adj=mid|-long|0}} iced haul road in [[Stetson, Maine]], by nightly application of water from a sprinkler sled, and strung a telephone line with frequent call boxes to dispatch sled trains over that road. The company estimated those three Lombard log haulers did the work of 60 horses.<ref>Holbrook (1961) pp.78-9</ref>
==History== The first two Lombard log haulers were used near [[Eustis, Maine]], in 1901 prior to construction of the [[Phillips and Rangeley Railroad#Eustis Railroad|Eustis Railroad]]. These early machines had an upright boiler and were steered by a team of horses.<ref name="auman"/> Most of the Lombard log haulers were used in [[Maine]] and [[New Hampshire]]. A few were used in [[Michigan]], [[Wisconsin]] and [[Russia]]. Lombard began building 6-cylinder [[petrol engine|gasoline]]-powered log haulers in 1914, produced a more powerful "Big 6" later, and built one [[Fairbanks-Morse]] [[Diesel engine]] hauler in 1934. The internal combustion log haulers (called Lombard tractors) were less powerful than the steam log haulers; and resembled a stake body truck on a skis and tracks chassis. The steam-powered haulers are thought to have been used as late as 1929.<ref>Holbrook (1961) p.79</ref> At least ten of the Lombard tractors were preserved at [[Eagle Lake (Maine)#Churchill Lake Dam|Churchill Depot]] as recently as the 1960s.<ref>{{cite book |last=Strout |first=W. Jerome |authorlink = |title =75 Years The Bangor and Aroostook |publisher =[[Bangor and Aroostook Railroad]] |volume = |edition = |date =1966 |location =[[Bangor, Maine]] |page =45 |isbn =}}</ref>
==Legacy== Antarctic [[Mount Lombard]] was named in recognition of the Lombard Log Hauler as the first application of knowledge of snow mechanics to trafficability.<ref name=gnis>{{cite gnis | type = antarid | id = 8977| name = Mount Lombard | accessdate = 2013-06-28}}</ref> The Lombard Steam Log Hauler was designated a [[List of Historic Mechanical Engineering Landmarks|National Historic Mechanical Engineering Landmark]] in 1982 following nomination by the [[American Society of Mechanical Engineers]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.maine.gov/doc/parks/history/allagash/lombards/brochure.pdf|title=The Lombard Log Hauler A National Historic Engineering Landmark|publisher=State of Maine|accessdate=2011-02-07}}</ref>
Lombard Steam Log Haulers have been preserved and restored in: * [[Ashland, Maine]] * [[Maine Forest & Logging Museum]] in [[Bradley, Maine]] * Owls Head Transportation Museum in [[Owls Head, Maine]] * Lumberman's Museum in [[Patten, Maine]] * [[Clark's Trading Post]] in [[Lincoln, New Hampshire]] * [[Rhinelander, Wisconsin]] * [[Saskatchewan Western Development Museum]] in [[Saskatoon]] * [[Waterville, Maine]]
==Notes== {{Reflist}}
==References== * {{cite book| title=Yankee Loggers |author=Holbrook, Stewart H. |publisher=International Paper Company |year=1961}} * {{cite journal|author=Auman, Jim |title=Lombard log hauler |publisher=Railroad Model Craftman |date=December 1984}} * {{cite journal|author=Walker, Martitia |title=470 Railroad Club Newsletter |publisher=Emmons Lancaster |date=March 1981}} * {{cite journal|author=Springer, Elaine |title=Log Hauler in Wytopitlock |publisher=Maine Life |date=May 1973}}
{{Forestry tools}}

revision.comment: /* General information */Typo fixing, replaced: on September 2010 → in September 2010; nanotechnolgoy → nanotechnology per source.
revision.text:
{{Nanotechnology}}
'''Nanoreactors''' are a form of [[chemical reactor]] that are particularly in the disciplines of [[nanotechnology]] and [[nanobiotechnology]]. These special reactors are crucial in maintaining a working [[nanofoundry]]; which is essentially a [[foundry]] that manufactures products on a nanotechnological scale.
==Summary== ===General information=== Researchers in the [[Netherlands]] have succeeded in building nanoreactors that can perform one-pot multistep reactions - the next step towards artificial [[Cell (biology)|cell]]-like devices in addition for applications involving the [[Screening (medicine)|screening]] and [[diagnosis]] of a disease or illness.<ref>[http://www.nanowerk.com/spotlight/spotid=3066.php ''Another nanotechnology example of mimicking nature: nanoreactors for one-pot multistep reactions''] at NanoWerk</ref> A biochemical nanoreactor is created simply by unwrapping a [[virus|biological virus]] through scientific methods, eliminating its harmful contents, and re-assembling its protein coat around a single molecule of enzyme.<ref>[http://www.rsc.org/chemistryworld/News/2007/September/24090702.asp ''Viral nanoreactor captures single molecules''] at RSC.org</ref> The [[kinetic isotope effect]] is trapped in a single molecule within a membrane-based nanoreactor.<ref name="rsc2">[http://www.rsc.org/chemistryworld/News/2010/September/12091001.asp ''Isotope effect seen on single molecule''] at RSC.org</ref> This is a phenomenon that has been found by researchers in the [[United Kingdom]] during experiments done in September 2010.<ref name="rsc2"/> The kinetic isotope effect, where the rate of a reaction is influenced by the presence of an isotopic atom in solution, is an important principle for elucidating reaction mechanisms.<ref name="rsc2"/> This recent finding could open up new methods to study chemical reactions.<ref name="rsc2"/> They may even aid in the process of creating new (and even more powerful) nanoreactors.<ref name="rsc2"/>
Using [[nanocrystal]]s, a scalable and inexpensive process can ultimately create nanoreactors.<ref name="lbl">[http://www.lbl.gov/tt/techs/lbnl2012.html ''Hollow Nanocrystals and Nanoreactors''] at Berkeley Lab</ref> Researchers at the [[Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory]] in [[University of California, Berkeley|Berkeley]] have the ability to take advantage of the large difference in select components to create these nanocrystals and nanoreactors.<ref name="lbl"/> Nanocrystals are easier to use and less expensive than methods that employ [[sacrificial template]]s in the creation process of [[hollow particle]]s.<ref name="lbl"/> Catalyst particles are separated into [[Electron shell|shell]]s in order to prevent [[particle aggregation]].<ref name="lbl"/> Selective entry into the catalysis chamber reduces the likelihood of desired products undergoing secondary [[Chemical reaction|reaction]]s.<ref name="lbl"/>
Nanoreactors can also be built by controlling the positioning of two different [[enzyme]]s in the central [[Reservoir|water reservoir]] or the [[plastic]] membrane of synthetic nanoscopic bubbles.<ref name="sciencedaily">[https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2007/08/070820112825.htm ''Nanoreactors For Reaction Cascades''] at Science Daily</ref> Once the third enzyme is added into the surrounding solution, it becomes possible for three different enzymatic reactions to occur at once without interfering with each other (resulting in a "one-pot" reaction).<ref name="sciencedaily"/> The potential for nanoreactors can be demonstrated by binding the enzyme [[horseradish peroxidase]] into the membrane itself; trapping the enzyme [[glucose oxidase]].<ref name="sciencedaily"/> The surrounding solution would end up containing the enzyme [[lipase B]] with the [[glucose]] molecules containing four acetyl groups as the substrate.<ref name="sciencedaily"/> The resulting glucose would cross the membrane, become oxidized, and the horseradish peroxidase would convert the sample substrate ABTS (2,2’-azinobis(3-ethylbenzthiazoline-6-sulfonic acid)) into its radical cation.<ref name="sciencedaily"/>
===Abilities=== Nanoreactors can also be used to emulisfy water, create [[hydrogen fuel|hydrofuel]]s (which essentially blends 15% water into the refined diesel product), play a helpful role in the [[Chemical substance|chemical]] industry by allowing multiple streams of raw materials to exists in a single nanoreactor, manufacture personal care products (i.e., [[lotion]]s, [[Cream (pharmaceutical)|pharmaceutical cream]]s, [[shampoo]]s, [[Hair conditioner|conditioner]]s, [[shower gel]]s, [[deodorant]]s), and improve the food and beverage industries (by processing [[sauce]]s, [[purée]]s, [[cooking base]]s for soup, emulsifying [[drink|non-alcoholic beverage]]s, and [[salad dressing]]s).<ref name="ctinanotech">[http://www.ctinanotech.com/technology/cti-cavitation-industry-applications ''CTI Nano Reactors Applications''] at CTI Nanotech</ref>
Personal care goods can be enhanced by companies feeding multiple phases of material, using a mixing device with water, and creating instant [[emulsion]]s.<ref name="ctinanotech"/> These emulsions would come with smaller particles, are expected to have a longer [[shelf life]] and an give off an enhanced appearance when sold at retailers.<ref name="ctinanotech"/> The needs of the food and beverage industry can result in lower processing costs, more space, better efficiency, and lower equipment costs.<ref name="ctinanotech"/> This may bring down the cost of food and beverages for consumers; even alcoholic beverages that are subject to hidden [[Pigovian tax|sin taxes]].
Hydrofuel can be used to move heavy duty [[transport]]s, [[train]]s, earth-moving equipment (including [[bulldozer]]s), in addition to providing fuel to most [[boat]]s and [[ship]]s.<ref name="ctinanotech"/> Reduced pollution and increased fuel efficiency may come out of nanoreactor-produced hydrofuel.<ref name="ctinanotech"/> The increased usage of renewable energy may also help to improve the world's environment thanks to nanoreactors.<ref name="ctinanotech"/>
==References== {{reflist|2}}
{{Nanotech footer}} {{Levels of technological manipulation of matter}}
[[Category:Nanotechnology]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} {{Use British English|date=October 2013}} {{Infobox video game |title = Near |image = Nearlondonscreenshot.jpg |caption = Regent Street in NearLondon |developer = Near Global |publisher = Nearworld Investments |released = 7 December 2009 (Open Beta) |genre = [[Multiplayer]] [[Social]] [[Virtual World]] |modes = [[Single player]] [[Multiplayer]] |platforms = [[Windows XP]]
[[Windows Vista]]
[[Windows 7]] }} '''''NearGlobal''''' is a London, UK, based software developer and publisher of Near, a [[3D computer graphics|3D]] city browser platform and virtual world technology that delivers survey-accurate models of real-world cities that users can explore and interact with from their computer. The Near software was released in December 2009 with a public beta version incorporating the key shopping districts of London's West End.{{cite news|url=http://business.timesonline.co.uk/tol/business/industry_sectors/retailing/article6851490.ece|title=West End online for a 'virtual Christmas'|publisher=The Times|accessdate=2010-07-07 | location=London | first=Fiona | last=Hamilton | date=2009-09-28}} ==Purpose== NearGlobal describes the Near product as a discovery platform,{{cite web|date=2010-01-07|url=http://london.nearglobal.com/Features.aspx|title=Near features|publisher=NearGlobal|accessdate=2010-07-07|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100815060617/http://london.nearglobal.com/Features.aspx|archivedate=15 August 2010|df=dmy-all}} rather that a virtual world. Near allows for the seamless integration of existing web-based content into the 3D environment. ==Differentiation== Near differs significantly from virtual worlds such as [[Second Life]], [[Twinity]] and [[Blue Mars (video game)|Blue Mars]] by focusing more on the presentation of the environment than on its users. The Near software depicts users with blades of light{{cite web|date=2009-09-28|url=http://www.brandrepublic.com/news/941546/Liberty-M-S-sign-up-Londons-virtual-West-End/|title=Liberty and M&S sign-up to London's virtual West End|publisher=Brand Republic|accessdate=2010-07-07}} rather than with human avatars. ==See also== * [[Second Life]] * [[Twinity]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== ;Official sites * [http://london.nearglobal.com/ Near Beta] * [http://www.nearglobal.com/ Corporate Information] [[Category:Virtual reality companies]] [[Category:Hypermedia]]

{{no footnotes|date=June 2012}} '''OpenWebNet''' is a [[communications protocol]] developed by [[Bticino]] since 2000.
The OpenWebNet protocol allows a "high-level" interaction between a remote unit and [[Bus SCS]] of MyHome [[domotic]] system. The latest protocol evolution has been improved to allow interaction with well-known home automation systems like [[KNX (standard)|KNX]] and [[DMX512-A]] system, by using appropriate [[Gateway (telecommunications)|gateways]].
The OpenWebNet protocol is disclosed on MyOpen community.
==OpenWebNet Protocol== The protocol is thought to be independent from the used technology. For example, it is possible to use a supervisor software connected via [[Ethernet]], via serial [[RS-232]] or via [[USB]] to a gateway that is directly connected to a domotic system.
Everyone can require protocol message extension. It is enough to propose your own [[Request for Comments|RFC]]. It will be examined and disclosed if it respects ''OpenWebNet'' syntax.
===Syntax=== An ''OpenWebNet'' message is structured with variable length fields separated by the special character '*' and closed by '##'.
The characters admitted in the fields are numbers and the character “#”.
The structure of a message is therefore: *field1*field2*… *fieldN##
The following fields are admitted: WHO WHAT WHERE DIMENSION VALUE
'''WHO'''
It characterizes the domotic system function to which the OpenWebNet message is referred.
For example: WHO = 1, characterizes the messages for lighting system management.
'''WHAT'''
It characterizes an action to do or a status to read. For every WHO (and therefore for every function) there is a specific WHAT table.
The field WHAT can also contain optional parameters: WHAT#PAR1#PAR2… #PARn.
Example of actions: switch ON light, dimmer to 75%, switch DOWN shutter, radio ON, etc. Example of status: light ON, active alarm, battery unload, etc.
'''WHERE'''
It characterizes the set of objects to which the OpenWebNet message is referred. It can be a single object, a group of objects, a specific environment, the entire system, etc.
For every WHO (and therefore for every function) there is a specified WHERE table.
The tag WHERE can also contain optional parameters: WHERE#PAR1#PAR2… #PARn.
Example of where: all the lights of group 1, sensor 2 of zone 1 of alarm system, etc.
'''DIMENSION'''
Is a range of value that characterizes the dimension of the object to which the message is referred. For every WHO (and therefore for every function) there is a specific DIMENSION table.
It’s possible to require/to read/to write the value of one dimension. Every dimension has a prefixed number of values, described in VALUE field.
Example of dimension: sensor temperature, loudspeaker volume, firmware version of a device, etc.
'''VALUE'''
It characterizes the read/written value of a written/required/read dimension.
===Message=== There are 4 types of OpenWebNet Message:
*Command / Status Message *Status Request Message *Request/Read/Write Dimension Message *Acknowledge Message
''Command / Status Message'' *WHO*WHAT*WHERE##
''Status Request Message'' *#WHO*WHERE##
''Request/Read/Write Dimension Message'' Request: *#WHO*WHERE*DIMENSION## Read: *#WHO*WHERE*DIMENSION*VALUE1*...*VALUEn## Write: *#WHO*WHERE*#DIMENSION*VALUE1*...*VALUEn##
''Acknowledge Message'' ACK: *#*1## NACK: *#*0##
==Gateway OpenWebNet== It is possible to interact with the SCS [[home automation]] [[bus (computing)|bus]] by using a specific [[Gateway (telecommunications)|gateway]].
There are two typologies of gateways that allow a connection to the field bus by using different [[Technical standard|standard]] [[Communications protocol|protocol]]s: * Gateway [[Ethernet]] ([[Linux]]-based) * Gateway [[USB]] or [[RS232]]
===Gateway Ethernet=== The current implementation by BTicino is also an [[embedded system|embedded]] [[web server]]. It works as a translator between OpenWebNet messages via TCP/IP and the SCS messages transmitted on the SCS bus.
It is possible to control three different kinds of buses: * BUS SCS * [[KNX (standard)|KNX]] * [[Digital MultipleX|DMX]]
The Ethernet gateway offers two modes of authentication: * via a list of whitelisted IPAs * using a nonce-type password exchange (see in the external links for code)
===Gateway USB or RS232=== The gateway is an interface that works as a translator between the OpenWebNet messages transmitted on USB or serial and the SCS messages transmitted on the SCS bus.
==Functions== {| class="wikitable sortable" ! WHO value ! Function |- ! 0 | Scenario |- ! 1 | Lighting |- ! 2 | Automation |- ! 3 | Load control |- ! 4 | Temperature Control/Heating |- ! 5 | Burglar Alarm/Intrusion |- ! 6 | Door Entry System |- ! 7 | Video Door Entry System/multimedia |- ! 9 | Auxiliary |- ! 13 | Gateway/interfaces management |- ! 14 | Light+shutters actuators lock |- ! 15 | CEN/Scenario Scheduler, switch |- ! 16 | Sound System/Audio |- ! 17 | Scenario programming |- ! 18 | Energy Management |- ! 24 | Lighting Management |- ! 25 | CEN/Scenario Scheduler, buttons |- ! 1000 | Diagnostic |- ! 1001 | Automation diagnostic |- ! 1004 | Thermoregulation diagnostic failures |- ! 1013 | Device diagnostic |}
{| class="wikitable sortable" ! WHERE value ! Lighting Function |- ! 0 | General |- ! 1÷9 | Room 1÷9 |- ! 11÷99 | Light point 11÷99 |- ! #1÷#9 | Group 1÷9 |}
==Example== OpenWebNet message examples
'''Command Message'''
Switch Off of light 77 *1*0*77##
WHO = 1 WHAT = 0 WHERE = 77
'''Status Message'''
Scenario 1 of scenario unit 23 activated. *0*1*23##
WHO = 0 WHAT = 1 WHERE = 23
'''Request status message'''
Status request of probe 1 *#4*1##
WHO = 4 WHERE = 1
'''Request Dimension Message'''
Request of Temperature Measured, probe 44 *#4*44*0##
WHO = 4 WHERE = 44 DIMENSION = 0
'''Read Dimension Message'''
Temperature Measured, probe 44 *#4*44*0*0251*2##
WHO = 4 WHERE = 44 DIMENSION = 0 VALUE1 = 0251 (T=+25,1 °C) VALUE2 = 2 (System in "cooling mode")
'''Write Dimension Message'''
Volume set at 50%, environment 2 *#16*#2*#1*16*##
WHO = #16 WHAT = #2 WHERE = #1 DIMENSION = 1 VALUE1 = 16

[[File:Peacock Clock.jpg|thumb|Peacock Clock]] The '''Peacock Clock''' is a large [[automaton]] featuring three life-sized mechanical birds. It was manufactured by the [[entrepreneur]] [[James Cox (inventor)|James Cox]] in the 2nd half of the 18th century and through the influence of [[Grigory Potemkin]] it was acquired by [[Catherine the Great]] in 1781. Today it is a prominent exhibit in the collections of the [[Hermitage Museum]] in [[Saint Petersburg]]. The clock is also shown daily on the Russian TV channel [[Russia-K]].
==References== *Yuna Zek, Antonina Balina, Mikhail Guryev, Yuri Semionov: [https://web.archive.org/web/20080202131950/http://www.hermitagemuseum.org/html_En/12/2006/hm12_1_22.html ''The Peacock Clock''] - photos, history and description of the Peacock Clock at hermitagemuseum.org (website of the [[Hermitage Museum]], archived version)

{{Unreferenced|date=April 2009}}
[[Image:Mallet bag.JPG|thumb|335px|Mallet bag showing variety of mallets]]
A '''percussion mallet''' or '''beater''' is an object used to strike or beat a [[percussion instrument]] in order to produce its sound.
The term ''beater'' is slightly more general; A ''mallet'' is normally held in the hand while a ''beater'' may be foot or mechanically operated, for example in a [[bass drum pedal]]; ''Drum stick'' is less general still, but still applied to a wide range of beaters. Some mallets, such as a triangle wand, are normally used only with a specific instrument, while others are used on many different instruments.
Some mallets, such as [[vibraphone]] mallets, are normally just called ''mallets'', others have more specialised names including:
* [[Drum stick]]s, of many types, some used with a wide variety of instruments,. * [[Wand (percussion)|Wand]]s used to strike a [[triangle (musical instrument)|triangle]]. * [[Rute (music)|Rute]]s, used with many instruments. * Brushes, used particularly with [[snare drum]] but also with many other instruments. * [[Tipper (percussion)|Tipper]]s used to strike a [[bodhrán]]. * [[Hammer (percussion)|Hammer]]s, also just called ''mallets'' or ''dongers'', used with a [[xylophone]]. * [[Bachi]], used with Japanese [[taiko]] drums.
==Types==
===Drum sticks=== {{main|drum stick}}
Drum sticks are beaters normally used in pairs, with each held in one hand, and are similar to or derived from the [[snare drum]] sticks that were subsequently adopted for [[kit drumming]].
They are the most general-purpose beaters, and the term covers a wide variety of beaters, but they are mainly used for untuned percussion.
===Mallets=== <!-- This section is linked from [[Crash cymbal]] --> [[Image:Model 13 yarn mallets.JPG|thumb|Yarn mallets (model 13)]] [[Image:Timpani Mallets.JPG|thumb|Timpani Mallets]] [[File:Cartwheel mallets.JPG|thumb|Cartwheel mallets, with wooden shafts and heads of felt held between steel washers]] As well as being a general term for a hand-held beater, '''mallet''' is also used specifically to refer to a hand-held beater comprising a '''head''' connected to a thin shaft, and used in pairs. There are three main sorts:
* '''Unwrapped mallets''', used on [[glockenspiel]], [[xylophone]] and other instruments with keys made of durable material, have heads made of [[brass]], [[rubber]], [[nylon]], [[acrylic resin|acrylic]], [[wood]], or other hard materials. * '''Wrapped mallets''', mostly used on [[marimba]], [[vibraphone]] and other instruments with softer keys (though they can be used on more durable instruments as well), have heads of [[Composite material|kelon]], rubber, nylon, acrylic or other medium-hard materials wrapped in softer materials like yarn, cord or latex. Wrapped mallets are also the mallets of choice to play [[suspended cymbal]], though drum set players typically simply use drum sticks instead. * '''[[Felt]] mallets''' or '''cartwheel mallets''' have heads composed of layers of felt, held between two steel washers. They are mainly used on untuned percussion, and in the context of [[kit drumming]] are referred to as ''soft sticks''.
Mallet shafts are commonly made of [[rattan]], [[birch]], or synthetic materials such as [[fibreglass]].
Different mallets are used primarily to alter the [[timbre]] of the mallet instrument being played. Generally, mallets composed of softer materials will stick to the instrument for longer as they bounce off of it, which gives a deeper sound made up of lower frequencies. Harder materials tend to bounce off quicker, and as they stick to the instrument for a shorter amount of time, they tend to be able to excite more of the higher frequencies, giving the sound a higher pitch with more overtones. Mallet choice is typically left up to the performer, though some compositions specify if a certain sound is desired by the composer.
Players frequently employ two mallets in a matched grip or four mallets in a four-mallet grip; however, use of up to six mallets is not uncommon. More than two mallets may be used even when no [[Chord (music)|chord]]s are called for by the composer so that the performer has a wider range of timbres from which to select or to facilitate performance of music that moves rapidly between high and low, and if hit properly can switch between the two [[Pitch (music)|pitch]]es.
===Brushes=== <!-- This section is linked from [[Ride cymbal]] -->
[[Image:Spazzole-brushes.jpg|thumb|Brushes in use on a [[snare drum]]]] Brushes are a set of bristles connected to a handle so that the bristles make a rounded fan shape. They are often used in [[jazz]] or [[blues]] music, but also in other genres such as [[rock music|rock]], [[country music|country]] and [[pop music|pop]]. The bristles can be made of metal or plastic; the handles are commonly made of wood or aluminum, and are often coated with rubber. Some brushes are telescoping so that the bristles can be pulled inside a hollow handle and the fan made by the bristles can be of variable length, width and density. Retracting the bristles also protects the brush when it is not being used. The non-bristled end of the brush may end in a loop or a ball.
===Rutes=== {{Main|Rute (music)}} [[File:Rutes and nylon brushes.JPG|thumb|Rutes and nylon brushes: [[Pro-Mark]] Hot Rod (19 canes), Pro-Mark Lightning Rod (7 canes), Livingstone (19 canes), [[Vater Percussion|Vater]] AcouStick (7 canes plus 6 nylon strips), [[Latin Percussion|LP]] light brush partly extended, the same brush fully extended]] A rute or multi-rod consists of several thin sticks that are bound together to form one stick. Its sound is midway between a stick and a brush.
Long used in orchestral music, in the mid 20th century rutes also became popular for many other purposes including [[kit drumming]] and [[bodhrán]].
By dissipating much of the energy of the stroke within the stick, a rute allows a drummer to achieve both a tone and a playing action that would normally be associated with quite loud playing, but at a moderate or even low volume. The tone produced by many can be adjusted by adjusting the position of one of the bands holding the bundle together.
==Major percussion mallet companies== *[[Mike Balter]] *[[Vic Firth]] *[[Innovative Percussion]] *[[Malletech]] *[[Vater Percussion|Vater]] *[[Regal Tip]] *[[Zildjian]] *[[Pro-Mark]] *Easton Ahead *[[Shaw (percussion mallet company)|Shaw]] *[[Stunner (percussion mallet company)|Stunner]] *[[Resta-Jay Percussions]] *[[Marimba One]] *[[Marimbaworks]] *[[Studio 49]] *[[A. Putnam]] *[[Headhunters (company)|Headhunters]] *Los Cabos *[[Ayotte]]

{{Infobox industrial process | name = Plasma Arc gasification | image = | caption = | type = Chemical | sector = Waste management
Energy | technologies = Plasma arc
Plasma electrolysis | feedstock = Municipal and industrial waste
[[Biomass]]
Solid [[hydrocarbons]] | product = [[Syngas]]
[[Slag]]
Separated metal scrap | companies = | facility = | inventor = | year = | developer = }} '''Plasma gasification''' is an extreme thermal process using [[Plasma (physics)|plasma]] which converts [[organic matter]] into a [[syngas]] (synthesis gas) which is primarily made up of [[hydrogen]] and [[carbon monoxide]]. A [[plasma torch]] powered by an [[electric arc]], is used to ionize gas and [[Catalysis|catalyze]] organic matter into [[syngas]] with [[slag]] {{Cite journal | display-authors = 4 | last1 = Moustakasa | first1 = K. | last2 = Fattab|first2 = D. | last3 = Malamisa |first3 = S. | last4 = Haralambousa |first4 = K. | last5 = Loizidoua|first5 = M. | title = Demonstration plasma gasification/vitrification system for effective hazardous waste treatment | journal = [[Journal of Hazardous Materials]] | volume = 123 | issue = 1–3 | pages = 120–126 | date = 2005-08-31 | url= http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0304389405001585 | doi = 10.1016/j.jhazmat.2005.03.038 | accessdate =2012-03-08 | subscription = yes}} {{Cite journal | display-authors = 4 | last1 = Kalinenko | first1 = R. A. | last2 = Kuznetsov |first2 = A. P. | last3 = Levitsky |first3 = A. A. | last4 = Messerle |first4 = V. E. | last5 = Mirokhin |first5 = Y. | last6 = Polak |first6 = L. S. | last7 = Sakipov |first7 = Z. B. | last8 = Ustimenko |first8 = A. B. | title = Pulverized coal plasma gasification | journal = [[Plasma Chemistry and Plasma Processing]] | volume = 13 | issue = 1 | pages = 141–167 | date = 1993 | url= http://www.springerlink.com/content/qx506h01079341l5/ | doi = 10.1007/BF01447176 | accessdate =2012-03-08 | subscription = yes}} {{Cite book | last1 = Messerle |first1 = V. E. | last2 = Ustimenko |first2 = A. B. | editor1-last = Syred | editor1-first = Nick | editor2-last = Khalatov | editor2-first = Artem | title = Advanced Combustion and Aerothermal Technologies. Environmental Protection and Pollution Reductions | chapter = Solid Fuel Plasma Gasification | publisher = Springer Netherlands | isbn = 978-1-4020-6515-6 | pages = 141–156 | date = 2007 | url= http://www.springerlink.com/content/n0u2236g59w08236/ | doi = 10.1007/978-1-4020-6515-6 | accessdate =2012-03-08 | subscription = yes}} remaining as a byproduct. It is used commercially as a form of [[waste treatment]] and has been tested for the gasification of [[municipal solid waste]], [[biomass]], [[industrial waste]], [[hazardous waste]], and solid [[hydrocarbons]], such as [[coal]], [[oil sands]], [[Petroleum coke|petcoke]] and [[oil shale]]. == Process == Small plasma torches typically use an [[inert gas]] such as [[argon]] where larger torches require [[nitrogen]]. The [[electrode]]s vary from [[copper]] or [[tungsten]] to [[hafnium]] or [[zirconium]], along with various other [[alloy]]s. A strong electric current under high voltage passes between the two electrodes as an [[electric arc]]. Pressurized inert gas is [[Ionization|ionized]] passing through the plasma created by the arc. The torch's temperature ranges from {{convert|4000|to|25000|F|C|-2}}. {{cite web | url= http://www.recoveredenergy.com/d_plasma.html | title= The Recovered Energy System: Discussion on Plasma Gasification | accessdate= 2008-10-20}} The temperature of the plasma reaction determines the structure of the plasma and forming gas. {{Cite journal | volume = 44 | issue = 6 | pages = 823–828 | last1 = Bratsev | first1 = A. N. | first2 = V. E. | last2 = Popov | first3 = A. F. | last3 = Rutberg | first4 = S. V. | last4 = Shtengel’ | title = A Facility for Plasma Gasification of Waste of Various Types | journal = High temperature | accessdate = 2013-03-12 | year = 2006 | url = http://www.springerlink.com/index/R82T86R6625446Q8.pdf | subscription = yes}} The waste is heated, melted and finally [[Vaporization|vaporized]]. Only at these extreme conditions can molecular [[Dissociation (chemistry)|dissociation]] occur by breaking apart [[Covalent bond|molecular bonds]]. [[molecule|Complex molecules]] are separated into individual [[atoms]]. The resulting elemental components are in a gaseous phase ([[syngas]]). Molecular dissociation using plasma is referred to as "plasma [[pyrolysis]]."{{Cite journal | volume = 37 | issue = 19 | pages = 4463–4467 | last = Huang | first = H. |author2=Lan Tang |author3=C. Z. Wu | title = Characterization of Gaseous and Solid Product from Thermal Plasma Pyrolysis of Waste Rubber | journal = Environmental Science & Technology | accessdate = 2013-03-12 | date = 2003 | url = http://pubs.acs.org/doi/abs/10.1021/es034193c | doi=10.1021/es034193c |bibcode = 2003EnST...37.4463H }} === Feedstocks === The feedstock for plasma waste treatment is most often [[municipal solid waste]], [[organic waste]], or both. Feedstocks may also include [[biomedical waste]] and [[Dangerous goods|hazmat]] materials. Content and consistency of the waste directly impacts performance of a plasma facility. Pre-sorting and recycling useful material before gasification provides consistency. Too much inorganic material such as metal and construction waste increases slag production, which in turn decreases [[syngas]] production. However, a benefit is that the slag itself is chemically inert and safe to handle (certain materials may affect the content of the gas produced, however). Shredding waste before entering the main chamber helps to increase syngas production. This creates an efficient transfer of energy which ensures more materials are broken down.{{cite web|url=http://science.howstuffworks.com/environmental/energy/plasma-converter.htm| title=How Stuff Works- Plasma Converter|accessdate=2012-09-09}} For improved processing steam is sometimes added into the plasma gasification process. === Yields === Pure highly calorific [[syngas|synthesis gas]] consists predominantly of [[carbon monoxide]] (CO) and [[hydrogen]] (H2). {{cite web | url= http://www.netl.doe.gov/technologies/coalpower/gasification/gasifipedia/4-gasifiers/4-1-4-1a_westinghouse.html | title= Plasma Gasification | publisher= [[United States Department of Energy]] | accessdate= 2010-08-07 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20100813175346/http://www.netl.doe.gov/technologies/coalpower/gasification/gasifipedia/4-gasifiers/4-1-4-1a_westinghouse.html | archive-date = 2010-08-13 | dead-url = yes}} [[Inorganic compound]]s in the waste stream are not broken down but melted, which includes glass, ceramics, and various metals. The high temperature and lack of oxygen prevents the formation of many toxic compounds such as [[furan]]s, [[dioxins and dioxin-like compounds|dioxins]], [[NOx|nitrogen oxides]], or [[sulfur dioxide]] in the flame itself. However, dioxins are formed during cooling of the syngas. Metals resulting from plasma [[pyrolysis]] can be recovered from the slag and eventually sold as a commodity. Inert slag produced from some processes is granulated and can be used in construction. A portion of the syngas produced feeds on-site turbines, which power the plasma torches and thus support the feed system. This is self-sustaining electric power. === Equipment === Some plasma gasification reactors operate at [[Pressure#Negative pressures|negative pressure]], but all attempt to recover both{{Cite patent | last = Camacho | first = Salvador L. | title = Method for the Gasification of Carbonaceous Matter by Plasma Arc Pyrolysis | accessdate = 2013-03-12 | date = 1980-01-01 | url = http://www.google.com/patents?id=WtwxAAAAEBAJ }} gaseous and solid resources. == Advantages == The main advantages of plasma torch technologies for waste treatment are: * Clean destruction of hazardous waste{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1088/0741-3335/47/5A/016 | issn = 0741-3335 | volume = 47 | issue = 5A | pages = A219 | last = Tendler | first = Michael |author2=Philip Rutberg |author3=Guido van Oost | title = Plasma Based Waste Treatment and Energy Production | journal = Plasma Physics and Controlled Fusion | accessdate = 2013-03-19 | date = 2005-05-01 | url = http://iopscience.iop.org/0741-3335/47/5A/016 |bibcode = 2005PPCF...47A.219T }} * Preventing hazardous waste from reaching landfills {{Cite patent | last = Springer | first = Marlin D. | author2 = William C. Burns | author3 = Thomas Barkley | title = Apparatus and Method for Treating Hazardous Waste | accessdate = 2013-03-20 | date = 1996-07-09 | url = http://www.google.com/patents?id=FRMmAAAAEBAJ }} {{Cite patent | last = Titus | first = Charles H. | author2 = Daniel R. Cohn | author3 = Jeffrey E. Surma | title = Arc Plasma-Melter Electro Conversion System for Waste Treatment and Resource ... | accessdate = 2013-03-20 | date = 1997-09-16 | url = http://www.google.com/patents?id=GBsnAAAAEBAJ }} * Some processes are designed to recover fly ash, bottom ash, and most other particulates, for 95% or better diversion from landfills, and no harmful emissions of [[toxic waste]] {{Cite journal | doi = 10.1016/j.wasman.2006.07.027 | issn = 0956-053X | volume = 27 | issue = 11 | pages = 1562–1569 | display-authors = 4 | last = Lemmens | first = Bert |author2=Helmut Elslander |author3=Ive Vanderreydt |author4=Kurt Peys |author5=Ludo Diels |author6=Michel Oosterlinck |author7=Marc Joos | title = Assessment of Plasma Gasification of High Caloric Waste Streams | journal = Waste Management | accessdate = 2013-03-20 | date = 2007 | url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0956053X06002595 }} * Potential production of vitrified slag which could be used as construction material {{Cite journal | volume = 49 | issue = 8 | pages = 2264–2271 | last = Mountouris | first = A. |author2=E. Voutsas |author3=D. Tassios | title = Plasma Gasification of Sewage Sludge: Process Development and Energy Optimization | journal = Energy Conversion and Management | accessdate = 2013-03-20 | date = 2008 | url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0196890408000502 | doi=10.1016/j.enconman.2008.01.025 }} * Processing of [[Biodegradable waste|organic waste]] into combustible [[syngas]] for [[electric power]] and [[thermal energy]] {{Cite journal | volume = 34 | issue = 4B | pages = 1587–1593 | last = Leal-Quirós | first = Edbertho | title = Plasma Processing of Municipal Solid Waste | journal = Brazilian Journal of Physics | accessdate = 2013-03-20 | date = 2004 | url = http://www.scielo.br/scielo.php?pid=S0103-97332004000800015&script=sci_arttext | doi=10.1590/S0103-97332004000800015 | bibcode=2004BrJPh..34.1587L }} * Production of [[Value added|value-added]] products (metals) from slag {{Cite journal | volume = 16 | issue = 5 | pages = 417–422 | last = Jimbo | first = Hajime | title = Plasma Melting and Useful Application of Molten Slag | journal = Waste management | accessdate = 2013-03-20 | date = 1996 | url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0956053X96000876 | doi=10.1016/S0956-053X(96)00087-6 }} * Safe means to destroy both [[medical waste|medical]] {{Cite journal | volume = 48 | issue = 4 | pages = 1331–1337 | last = Huang | first = Haitao |author2=Lan Tang | title = Treatment of Organic Waste Using Thermal Plasma Pyrolysis Technology | journal = Energy Conversion and Management | accessdate = 2013-03-12 | date = 2007 | url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0196890406002512 | doi=10.1016/j.enconman.2006.08.013 }} and many [[hazardous waste]]s. * Gasification with starved combustion and rapid quenching of syngas from elevated temperatures can avoid the production of dioxins and furans that are common to incinerators * Air emissions can be cleaner than landfills and some incinerators. == Disadvantages == Main disadvantages of plasma torch technologies for waste treatment are: * Large initial investment costs relative to that of alternatives, including landfill {{Cite journal | doi = 10.1109/TSTE.2010.2061242 | issn = 1949-3029 | volume = 1 | issue = 3 | pages = 125–130 | last = Pourali | first = M. | title = Application of Plasma Gasification Technology in Waste to Energy #x2014;Challenges and Opportunities | journal = IEEE Transactions on Sustainable Energy | bibcode = 2010ITSE....1..125P }} and [[incineration]]. * Operational costs are high relative to that of incineration. * Little or even negative net energy production. * Wet feed stock results in less syngas production and higher energy consumption. * Frequent maintenance and limited plant availability. * For some early technologies, the plasma torch [[Plume (fluid dynamics)|plume]] reduced the diameter of the sampler orifice over time, necessitating frequent maintenance.{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1590/S0103-97332004000800015 | issn = 0103-9733 | volume = 34 | issue = 4B | pages = 1587–1593 | last = Leal-Quirós | first = Edbertho | title = Plasma Processing of Municipal Solid Waste | journal = Brazilian Journal of Physics | accessdate = 2013-03-20 | date = December 2004 | url = http://www.scielo.br/scielo.php?pid=S0103-97332004000800015&script=sci_arttext | bibcode=2004BrJPh..34.1587L }} ==Commercialization== {{main article|Plasma gasification commercialization}} Plasma torch gasification is used commercially for waste disposal {{cite web |url=http://www.peat.com/national_cheng.html |title=National Cheng Kung University - Tainan, Taiwan |publisher=PEAT International |accessdate=2009-04-09}} {{Cite report |last=Williams |first=R.B. |last2=Jenkins |first2=B.M. |last3=Nguyen |first3=D. |title=Solid Waste Conversion: A review and database of current and emerging technologies |page=23 |publisher=[[University of California, Davis]], Department of Biological and Agricultural Engineering | date=December 2003 |url=http://biomass.ucdavis.edu/pages/reports/Conversion-PhaseI_IWM-C0172.pdf |format=PDF |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070415070400/http://biomass.ucdavis.edu/pages/reports/Conversion-PhaseI_IWM-C0172.pdf |archivedate=2007-04-15}} {{cite web |url = http://www.zerowasteottawa.com/en/About-Project/ |title = About the Project |publisher = A Partnership for a Zero Waste Ottawa |accessdate = 2009-04-10 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090420003312/http://www.zerowasteottawa.com/en/About-Project/ |archivedate = 2009-04-20 |df = }} {{cite news |first=Laura |last=Czekaj |title=Mechanical problems plague Plasco |newspaper=[[Ottawa Sun]] |publication-date=2008-12-07 }} {{cite web |url = http://www.afsoc.af.mil/news/story.asp?id=123253735 |title = AFSOC makes 'green' history while investing in future |publisher = US Air Force Special Operations Command |accessdate = 2011-04-28 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110509083529/http://www.afsoc.af.mil/news/story.asp?id=123253735 |archivedate = 2011-05-09 |df = }} {{cite news |title=INEOS Bio Commercializes bioenergy technology in Florida |work=[[Biomass Program]] |date=2011-11-21 |url=http://www1.eere.energy.gov/biomass/pdfs/ibr_arraprojects_ineos.pdf |format=PDF}} {{Cite web | title = The Plasma Arc Waste Destruction System to Reduce Waste Aboard CVN-78, pg. 13 | publisher = Seaframe - Carderock Division Publication | date = 2008 | url = http://www.dtic.mil/cgi-bin/GetTRDoc?Location=U2&doc=GetTRDoc.pdf&AD=ADA519815}} {{cite press release |url = http://alternrg.com/press_release_94553 |title = Alter NRG Announces Commissioning of Biomass Gasifier at Waste To Liquids Facility in China |publisher = Alter NRG |accessdate = 2013-01-29 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20130307175931/http://www.alternrg.com/press_release_94553 |archivedate = 2013-03-07 |df = }}{{cite news|url=http://www.waste-management-world.com/articles/2013/04/plasma-gasification-waste-to-energy-air-products-teesside-uk-government.html|title=Second Plasma Gasification Plant for Teesside Following Government Deal|last=Messenger|first=Ben|date=12 April 2013|publisher=Waste Management News}}{{Cite press release|title=Air Products Will Exit Energy-from-Waste Business|date=2016-04-04|url=http://www.airproducts.com/Company/news-center/2016/04/0404-air-products-will-exit-energy-from-waste-business.aspx|accessdate=2016-04-06}}{{Citation|title=Air Products abandons plans for plasma-based energy from waste plants in Tees Valley|date=2016-04-05|url=http://www.newpower.info/2016/04/air-products-abandons-plans-for-plasma-based-energy-from-waste-plants-in-tees-valley/|accessdate=2016-04-06}} at a total of five sites worldwide representing to a combined design capacity of 200 tonnes waste per day, of which 100 tonnes per day is biomass waste. ==Military Use== The US Navy is employing Plasma Arc Waste Destruction System (PAWDS) on its latest generation [[Gerald R. Ford-class aircraft carrier|''Gerald R. Ford''-class aircraft carrier]]. The compact system being used will treat all combustible solid waste generated on board the ship. After having completed factory acceptance testing in Montreal, the system is scheduled to be shipped to the Huntington Ingalls shipyard for installation on the carrier.{{Citation | title = The Plasma Arc Waste Destruction System to Reduce Waste Aboard CVN-78, pg. 13 | publisher = Seaframe - Carderock Division Publication | date = 2008 | url = http://www.dtic.mil/cgi-bin/GetTRDoc?Location=U2&doc=GetTRDoc.pdf&AD=ADA519815}} ==See also== * [[Gasification]] * [[List of plasma (physics) applications articles]] * [[Plasma (physics)]] * [[Staged reforming]] * [[Waste management]] * [[Waste to energy]] * [[Northeast of England Process Industry Cluster]] NEPIC ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} == External links == * [http://www.gasification.org Gasification Technologies Council] * [http://www.plazarium.com PLAZARIUM Corporation] * [http://www.westinghouse-plasma.com Westinghouse Plasma Corporation] * [http://www.tetronics.com Tetronics International] * [http://www.peat.com PEAT International] - [http://www.peat.com/process_overview.html Plasma Thermal Destruction & Recovery Technology (PTDR)] * [http://www.advancedplasmapower.com/index.php?action=PublicContactUsDisplay Advanced Plasma Power] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20120302212301/http://www.dti.gov.uk/files/file33251.pdf Department of Trade and Industry - Using thermal plasma technology to create a valuable product from hazardous waste] * [http://www.pyrogenesis.com PyroGenesis Canada Inc.] * [http://www.reinc.co Responsible Energy Inc.] * [http://www.plasmapowerllc.com Plasma Power, LLC] {{DEFAULTSORT:Plasma Arc Waste Disposal}} [[Category:Sustainable technologies]] [[Category:Plasma processing]] [[Category:Thermal treatment]]

'''[http://www.pokito.net Pokito]''' is a type of collapsible, reusable [[coffee cup]] designed by [[Canada|Canadian]] inventor Andrew Brooks<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://pokito.net/about/|title=About - pokito|work=pokito|access-date=2017-12-11|language=en-US}}</ref> in the United Kingdom. The cup is manufactured in England. Brooks is marketing the pokito cup though his company, Pocket Enterprises UK, and has completed a Kickstarter campaign to raise money to fund initial production. The Pokito Kickstarter campaign is in the top 1% of all time Kickstarter campaigns.
The cup adjusts to three sizes.<ref>[https://www.thestar.com/business/2016/10/11/is-creating-a-reusable-coffee-cup-a-planet-saver-or-a-mugs-game-wells.html "Is creating a reusable coffee cup a planet saver or a mug's game? Wells"]. ''Toronto Star'', October 12, 2016, page B6.</ref><ref>[http://www.oxfordmail.co.uk/news/news_bites/14806177.Coffee_shop_tackles_waste_with_reusable_cups/ "Coffee shop in Abingdon tackles waste with reusable cups"]. ''Oxford Mail'', 17 Oct 2016 / Sophie Grubb</ref> It flattens to about 4.5 cm in height when not in use, and so can be stored in a pocket or purse.<ref>[http://www.trendhunter.com/trends/pokito "Pokito' is a New Solution to Disposable Coffee Cup Waste"]. ''Trend Hunter'', Katherine Pendrill, Aug 2, 2016</ref> Remaining dregs of coffee are kept inside without leakage.<ref>[http://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/collapsible-coffee-cup-could-save-tax-and-trees-kzj72l7kr "Collapsible coffee cup could save tax and trees"]. ''The Times'', Tom Whipple, Science Editor, October 14 2016</ref><ref>[http://www.pressreader.com/uk/daily-mail/20161105/282570197670713 "The reusable coffee cup you can squash up and put in your bag"]. ''Daily Mail'', Sean Poulter, 5 November 2016</ref>
The pokito is designed to reduce the usage of disposable cups.<ref>[https://www.comunicaffe.com/collapsible-coffee-cup-save-tax-trees/ "Collapsible coffee cup could save tax and trees"]. ''International Communicaffe'', October 19, 2016</ref> It also saves energy if the cup is used more than 15 times.<ref>[http://www.thefoodrush.com/news/a-coffee-cup-that-fits-in-your-pocket/ "A Coffee Cup That Fits In Your Pocket"]. ''The Food Rush'', September 20, 2016</ref> <ref>[https://issuu.com/schofieldpublishingltd/docs/foodchain_issue_118_october_2016 "Cup debate continues"]. ''Food Chain magazine'', Issue 188, October 2016. page 15.</ref> It is made of a rubbery plastic called [[thermoplastic elastomer]] which is FDA approved.<ref>[http://plugin-magazine.com/living/pokito-the-adorable-pocket-sized-reusable-cup/ "Pokito, the adorable pocket-sized reusable cup"]. ''Plug-In'', Nov. 12, 2016</ref>
By the end of the campaign Brooks had raised £100,500 multiple times the original Kickstarter goal.<ref>[http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/entry/pokito-foldable-coffee-cup-good-for-planet_uk_58340da1e4b09025ba33302f "‘Pokito’ Foldable Coffee Cup Is Great News For The Planet (And Mornings)"]. ''The Huffington Post UK''. 22/11/2016 Natasha Hinde </ref>

[https://Pokito.net pokito.net]
